ruleset.name: JUnit
ruleset.description: These rules deal with different problems that can occur with JUnit tests.

rule.name: JUnitStaticSuite
rule.message: You have a suite() method that is not both public and static, so JUnit won't call it to get your TestSuite. Is that what you wanted to do?
rule.description: The suite() method in a JUnit test needs to be both public and static.

rule.name: JUnitSpelling
rule.message: You may have misspelled a JUnit framework method (setUp or tearDown)
rule.description: Some JUnit framework methods are easy to misspell.

property.name: xpath
property.value: //MethodDeclarator[(not(@Image = 'setUp') and translate(@Image, 'SETuP', 'setUp') = 'setUp') or (not(@Image = 'tearDown') and translate(@Image, 'TEARdOWN', 'tearDown') = 'tearDown')] [FormalParameters[count(*) = 0]] [ancestor::ClassOrInterfaceDeclaration[//ClassOrInterfaceType[pmd-java:typeof(@Image, 'junit.framework.TestCase','TestCase')] or //MarkerAnnotation/Name[pmd-java:typeof(@Image, 'org.junit.Test', 'Test')]]]

rule.name: JUnitAssertionsShouldIncludeMessage
rule.message: JUnit assertions should include a message
rule.description: JUnit assertions should include an informative message - i.e., use the three-argument version of assertEquals(), not the two-argument version.

rule.name: JUnitTestsShouldIncludeAssert
rule.message: JUnit tests should include assert() or fail()
rule.description: JUnit tests should include at least one assertion. This makes the tests more robust, and using assert with messages provide the developer a clearer idea of what the test does.

rule.name: TestClassWithoutTestCases
rule.message: This class name ends with 'Test' but contains no test cases
rule.description: Test classes end with the suffix Test. Having a non-test class with that name is not a good practice, since most people will assume it is a test case. Test classes have test methods named testXXX.

rule.name: UnnecessaryBooleanAssertion
rule.message: assertTrue(true) or similar statements are unnecessary
rule.description: A JUnit test assertion with a boolean literal is unnecessary since it always will evaluate to the same thing. Consider using flow control (in case of assertTrue(false) or similar) or simply removing statements like assertTrue(true) and assertFalse(false). If you just want a test to halt after finding an error, use the fail() method and provide an indication message of why it did.

property.name: xpath
property.value: //StatementExpression [ PrimaryExpression/PrimaryPrefix/Name[@Image='assertTrue' or @Image='assertFalse'] and PrimaryExpression/PrimarySuffix/Arguments/ArgumentList/Expression [PrimaryExpression/PrimaryPrefix/Literal/BooleanLiteral or UnaryExpressionNotPlusMinus[@Image='!'] /PrimaryExpression/PrimaryPrefix[Literal/BooleanLiteral or Name[count(../../*)=1]]] ] [ancestor::ClassOrInterfaceDeclaration[//ClassOrInterfaceType[pmd-java:typeof(@Image, 'junit.framework.TestCase','TestCase')] or //MarkerAnnotation/Name[pmd-java:typeof(@Image, 'org.junit.Test', 'Test')]]]

rule.name: UseAssertEqualsInsteadOfAssertTrue
rule.message: Use assertEquals(x, y) instead of assertTrue(x.equals(y))
rule.description: This rule detects JUnit assertions in object equality. These assertions should be made by more specific methods, like assertEquals.

rule.name: UseAssertSameInsteadOfAssertTrue
rule.message: Use assertSame(x, y) instead of assertTrue(x==y), or assertNotSame(x,y) vs assertFalse(x==y)
rule.description: This rule detects JUnit assertions in object references equality. These assertions should be made by more specific methods, like assertSame, assertNotSame.

rule.name: UseAssertNullInsteadOfAssertTrue
rule.message: Use assertNull(x) instead of assertTrue(x==null), or assertNotNull(x) vs assertFalse(x==null)
rule.description: This rule detects JUnit assertions in object references equality. These assertions should be made by more specific methods, like assertNull, assertNotNull.

rule.name: SimplifyBooleanAssertion
rule.message: assertTrue(!expr) can be replaced by assertFalse(expr)

rule.name: JUnitTestContainsTooManyAsserts
rule.message: JUnit tests should not contain more than ${maximumAsserts} assert(s).
rule.description: JUnit tests should not contain too many asserts. Many asserts are indicative of a complex test, for which it is harder to verify correctness. Consider breaking the test scenario into multiple, shorter test scenarios. Customize the maximum number of assertions used by this Rule to suit your needs.

property.name: maximumAsserts
property.description: Maximum number of Asserts in a test method

rule.name: UseAssertTrueInsteadOfAssertEquals
rule.message: Use assertTrue(x)/assertFalse(x) instead of assertEquals(true, x)/assertEquals(false, x) or assertEquals(Boolean.TRUE, x)/assertEquals(Boolean.FALSE, x).
rule.description: When asserting a value is the same as a literal or Boxed boolean, use assertTrue/assertFalse, instead of assertEquals.
